We did a virtual seminar, but Dr. Shanahan was very accommodating with office hours virtually as well.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The 18 page final paper in this class was the longest paper I've ever written, and I greatly appreciated Dr. Shanahan's thoughtful guidance through the research, drafting, and writing processes. Not only did I write a paper that I felt confident in and proud of, but I also walked away from the course with more insight into being an active and engaged participant in a small seminar. I also feel that my ability to be critical of assigned texts improved over the course of this semester, both through this course and through others.
I learned a lot about the history of immigration policy and also got the opportunity to continue working on my research/writing skills
I developed a comprehensive knowledge of the past few centuries of American immigration legislation, focusing on

This class gave such a comprehensive look at US Immigration History, right from the very beginning. Dr. Shanahan was fantastic at making sure we had a thorough look at some of the most important moments, eras and changes in the long history of US immigration policy. Of course we also learned important writing and research skills  Dr. Shanahan was very careful with his edits and comments on our research papers, ensuring we knew how to best improve. He gave better feedback than any other professor I had this semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The structure and assignments of this course were very strong, in that they encouraged me engage with my final paper subject early and also helped me hone some of the writing skills I would need for the final throughout the semester. I was grateful for the opportunity to analyze some primary and secondary sources and get feedback on that writing before turning towards my final. Overall, I was quite satisfied with the course, but think that discussion could possibly be improved by more guidance surrounding readings and perhaps an optional discussion board to post (very brief) questions or throughts before class meetings.

The best part about this course is Dr. Shanahan - he is the nicest and one of the most helpful people I've encountered in my time at Yale and his enthusiasm about students' work made the class worth taking. Definitely important to note that this is a class on immigration policy and not just immigration history in general. If you're not super interested in law/policy the readings could be a bit dense at times.

The greatest strength of this course was definitely the engagement of Professor Shanahanhe gives extremely thorough feedback on your writing and is genuinely determined to help you understand and engage with course material. I thought our discussions were always really interesting and I looked forward to class each week. One weakness is just that there is a lot of reading (sometimes almost a book a week) so that is worth keeping in mind.

A strength of the class is the way that Dr. Shanahan led discussion, asked fantastic questions, and structured the class in a way that facilitated engagement. The class was structured in a way that allowed us to read some of the best scholarship on immigration, paired with a primary source document that had synergy with the other readings. All in all, this allowed each week to be organized in a way that ensured the conversation was always on track. Dr. Shanahan also was careful to listen to our concerns as students (especially during a tough pandemic semester) and was kind and considerate with listening and keeping our research papers on track.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that this course went about as well as possible in a virtual format. There was occasional awkwardness or pauses, but nothing that detracted from the learning experience. Additionally, I greatly appreciated working in breakout rooms, and wouldn't mind seeing more of that in the future!
Generally just a standard seminar setup - the small class size was good for discussion/engagement given the pandemic

Virtual seminars were sometimes difficult due to connectivity issues, but I believe the course structure worked well overall. In addition, Professor Shanahan was always willing to meet over Zoom for office hours, which was great (and felt very similar to in person office hours!).

The online seminar was the best it could be in a virtual format. I found it was difficult for some professors to steer discussion and avoid silences, but Dr. Shanahan was able to direct the conversation well with pointed and thought-out guiding questions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I found it intellectually engaging, and was also very impressed with how the professor and structure of the course facilitated student learning and skill building.

I would definitely take this class for Dr. Shanahan - he's an incredibly kind/super engaged and enthusiastic teacher. The readings/subject material can be a bit dense at times if policy isn't really your thing.
Yes! Professor Shanahan is an incredibly engaging and insightful instructor, and his understanding and support throughout the course made it much easier to be successful despite the circumstances.

Yes! I would absolutely recommend this course or any other course taught by Professor Shanahan. He is extremely passionate about the course material, which makes it easy to stay engaged. The reading material for each seminar was generally well selected, and a great balance of primary and secondary sources, so our discussions were both thorough and eye-opening. If you are at all interested in immigration history and how legislation has evolved, I would definitely recommend this course!

I would totally recommend US Immigration Policy to any student interested in the subject or History generally. Dr. Shanahan will make it worth it with his thoughtful dicussion guiding questions and the class members' thoughtful conversation about some of the best readings on immigration policy throughout history.
